Speaker: nick
Dialogue: When I came back from New York I was disgusted.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: One man...? Mr. Carraway?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Gatsby...

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Was he a friend of yours?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: He was... the single most hopeful person I have ever met... And am ever likely to meet again. There was something about him...

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Where did you meet him?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: At a party. In New York.

Speaker: radio voice
Dialogue: The stock market hit another record high today!

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Gatsby.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: So... He was your neighbor?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: My neighbor? No, Gatsby was-- Well-- If I think about it... The history of the summer really began the night I drove over to my cousin Daisy's for dinner...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Oh, I'm selling bonds now Tom... with Walter Chase's outfit--

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Never heard of em.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: CAN'T--

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Catch up with the old wolf pack?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Big day on the new job tomorrow--

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Nonsense! We're going.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: First team, all-American!

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Do they miss me in Chicago?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Oh, yes. About a dozen people send their love.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: How gorgeous.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: They're absolutely in mourning... They're crying...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: NO--

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: They're wailing...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: NO--

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: They're screaming, they're shouting...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: NO--

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: "Daisy Buchanan, we can't live without you!"

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: I'm p-paralyzed with happiness...!

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I've seen your face on the cover of "Sporting Life". Nick Carraway...

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: I've been lying on that sofa for as long as I can remember...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: I know! This summer I'll sort of, fling you and Jordan together...

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: I'm not listening to a word!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Nick, Daisy tells me you're over at WEST EGG;

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Well, my little shack is cardboard box at eighty a month.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Your life is adorable.

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: I know somebody in West Egg.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I don't know a single--

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Oh, you must know Gatsby.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Gatsby?

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: Madame, le diner est servi!

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Would you like to hear a family secret? Its about the butler's nose...

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Things went from bad to worse...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Nicky... I heard a rumor, that you were getting married to a girl out west...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Its a libel, I'm too poor.

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: They have to be old so they die quickly...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Can't we talk about something else? Anything? Crops? You're making me feel uncivilized Daisy--

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Civilization's going to pieces! Have you read 'The Rise of the Colored Empires' by this fellow Goddard?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Why no...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Everyone ought to read it. The idea is that its up to us, the dominant race, to watch out, or these other races...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Tom's been very profound lately. He reads deep books with long words in THEM

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: It's been proved. Its scientific.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: We've got to beat them down.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Excuse me... I'll be right back.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: I'm sorry...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Well, this Mr. Gatsby you spoke of is my neighbor...

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Shhhh... Don't talk. I want to hear what happens.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Is something happening?

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: I thought everybody knew.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I don't.

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Tom's got some woman in New York.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Got some woman?

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: She might have the decency not to telephone at dinner-time... Don't you think?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: I just love seeing you at my table Nicky. You remind me of a rose, an absolute rose... Doesn't he?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I'm not even faintly like a rose--

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: So... After dinner Nick wanted to go into town. Right Nick? To the Yale club.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Nicky, stay--

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I have to work early.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Nonsense. Its only for a drink or two.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Oh Nicky...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Its just, well, you see, I think everything's terrible anyhow. You know I've been everywhere and seen everything and done everything, and I've had very bad time Nicky... I'm pretty cyncical about everything.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Your daughter; I suppose she talks, and... eats, and everything?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Pammy? Oh yes...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: The green light.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Green light?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I don't want to talk about this Doctor.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Then write about it.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Write?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Yes. Write.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Why would I do that?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: After all, you said that writing brought you solace, once upon a time.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Yeah, well. It didn't bring anyone else much solace... I wasn't any good.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: No one need ever read it. You can always burn it.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: What would I write about?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Anything. Whatever you can't quite talk about; a memory; a thought; a place... Write it down.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: A place...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Come on--!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Trust me!

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Wait a second would you!?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Dominate Nick! Dominate!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Hello Wilson! How's business?

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: I can't complain. When are you going to sell me that car?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I've got my man working on it.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Works pretty slow, don't he?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Maybe I'd better sell it somewhere else?

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: I don't mean that, I just...

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: If its business you're talking, you should be talking to me...  Get some chairs why don't you; so somebody can sit down...

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Oh, sure... Sure...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Mrs. Wilson... Nick Carraway.

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: A pleasure...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Nick's a writer...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I'm in bonds, actually...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Get on the next train.

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: Now...? Are we gettin' that dog?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Whatever you want. And you can call up your sister...  She'll like him...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Oh no, that's alright, I'm busy...

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: Catherine's said to be very good looking, by people who oughta know.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Really I can't...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Do you want to embarrass Myrtle...? That's rude.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I'm Catherine; ain't we havin' a party?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Oh, I'm... I'm not sure now's a good time-- I was just going--

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Nick Carraway.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: What's the matter? Don't ya like me?

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: It's just a crazy old thing. I slip it on when I don't care what I look like!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Get some ice Myrtle, before everyone goes to sleep.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Tom, I really should be going...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Nonsense...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Tom; I don't think-- Daisy's my--

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Listen Nick, you like to watch; I remember that from college. And that's OK, I make no judgment; but we've got a whole summer - do you want to sit on the sideline and watch, or do you want to play ball?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Yeah. Ain't we good enough for ya?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Hey Nick! McKee's in the artistic game.

Speaker: mckee
Dialogue: Photography.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Nick's artistic.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: mckee
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Ah, no, well, I write a little...

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Do you live on Long Island, too?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I live at West Egg.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Really? I was there at a party about a month ago. At a man named Gatsby's. Do you know him?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I live right next door to him...

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: He's a cousin of Kaiser Wilhelm's. You know, the evil German king...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Hey McKee, take a picture of that!

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Neither of them can stand who they're married to.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Doesn't she like Wilson either?

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: ...He's a greasy little scumbag!

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: No thanks; I feel just as good on nothing at all...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: My nerves are fine thanks...

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: ...I've got to get a massage, and a wave, and a collar for the dog, and one of those cute little ash-trays where you touch a spring, and a wreath with a black silk bow for mother's grave!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You've got no right to speak her name!

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: Daisy! Daisy! Daisy! I'll speak it whenever I want! Daisy! Dai--

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I have no clue how I got home.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Watching you...?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Yes. He was watching me. In fact, I know now that Gatsby was always watching me...

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: And how do you know that?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Because I got an invitation... I was the only one.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Do you know where I might find the host, Mr. Gatsby?

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: Mr. Gatsby? I've never seen him sir. Why, no one has...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Wow.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: I thought I might see you here...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: I remembered you lived next door...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Its like... an amusement park.

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Shall we?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Did you get an invitation?

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: People aren't invited to Gatsby's.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Well I was... I seem to be the only one. Who is this Gatsby?

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: He was a German spy during the war.

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Teddy Barton. Nick Carraway.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: A German spy...?

Speaker: nelson
Dialogue: No, no, no, no. He's the Kaiser's assassin.

Speaker: languid girl
Dialogue: I heard he killed a man once.

Speaker: nelson
Dialogue: Its true!

Speaker: lanuid girl
Dialogue: You look at him sometimes when he thinks no one's watching... I'll bet he killed a man.

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Kills for fun! Free of charge.

Speaker: nelson
Dialogue: Well he's already richer than God.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: You don't believe he killed a man do you...?

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Let's go find him, and you can ask him yourself...

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Oh, Mr. Gatsby...!  Shall I lead you into his clutches?

Speaker: owl eyes
Dialogue: You won't find him...!

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Phooey; I've met him!

Speaker: owl eyes
Dialogue: Which one; the Prince, the Spy, the Murderer? I've been wandering his halls drunk for about a week now - but no matter where I look, I can't find anyone who knows anything real about Mr. Gatsby.

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Well I don't care; he gives large parties - and I like large parties, they're so intimate; at small parties there isn't any privacy.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: But if that's true; what's all this for...?

Speaker: owl eyes
Dialogue: That, my dear fellow, is the question...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I didn't expect all this...

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: What did you expect?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I don't know...

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Disappointed?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Not in the slightest...

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Penny-less pantywaist!

Speaker: orchestra leader
Dialogue: Ladies and gentlemen, please make your way to the grand terrazzo; for the premiere of Mr. Vladimir Tostoff's "A Jazz History of the World", and accompanying fireworks!

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Look around you! Rich girls don't marry poor boys--

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Your face is familiar. Weren't you in the Third Division during the war?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Yes; The Ninth Battalion.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: I was in the Seventh. I knew I'd seen you somewhere before... Having a good time, old sport?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: He even sent me an invitation, but I still haven't met Mr. Gatsby, no one's met him; they say he's third cousin to the Kaiser and second cousin to the devil!

Speaker: man
Dialogue: I'm afraid I'm not a very good host, old sport... I'm Gatsby.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Oh.. I'm very sorry-- I... I've had so much to drink...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I thought you knew, old sport.

Speaker: herzog
Dialogue: Excuse me sir; Chicago on the wire.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I'm trying out my new hydroplane in the morning. Want to go with me, old sport?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: What time?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Any time that suits you.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I expected him to be...

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Old and fat?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Well, yes; young men don't just drift coolly out of nowhere and buy a palace on Long Island.

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: He told me once he was an Oxford man. However, I don't believe it...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: I don't know... I just don't believe he went there...

Speaker: herzog
Dialogue: I beg your pardon...

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Me?

Speaker: herzog
Dialogue: Yes, madame.

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Nick! Nick! I've just heard the most shocking thing; it all makes sense...

Speaker: teddy
Dialogue: Where have you been!? The car's waiting!

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Simply amazing! It all makes sense. It all makes sense...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: What makes sense...?

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Everything... But here I am tantalizing you...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: But...

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Nick. I'm sorry, I swore I wouldn't tell.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Sorry to keep her from you, old sport. Don't forget; we're going up in the hydroplane tomorrow morning.

Speaker: herzog
Dialogue: Philadelphia on the phone, sir.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Good night, old sport...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Good night. Thank you.

Speaker: owl eyes
Dialogue: Whazza matter!? We run outta gas!?

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Come and see me... We'll have tea! I'm in the phone-book!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Its pretty isn't it, old sport...? Haven't you seen it before? Its all a custom job. Supercharged engine. Get dressed... We're having lunch!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Ah... well... Ah... Look here, old sport... What's your opinion of me, anyhow?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: My... opinion?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Yes, yes, your opinion!

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: WELL--

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I'll tell you God's truth. God's truth about myself!  I am the son of some very wealthy people from the Middle-West; sadly, all dead now... I was brought up in America, but educated at Oxford; because all my ancestors have been educated there for many years. You see, it's a... a family tradition.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: After that I lived like a young Prince in all the capitals of Europe!

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Europe?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Yes, Europe! Paris; Venice; Rome; Vienna, Zurich, Helsinki... Collecting jewels, chiefly rubies, hunting big game, painting, a little, things for myself mostly, and trying to forget something very sad that happened to me long ago...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Then came the war, old sport...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: It was a great relief and I tried very hard to die, but I seemed to bear an enchanted life...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: In the Argonne Forest I took my machine gun detachment so far forward... We were outnumbered five to one. There was a half mile gap on either side of us where the infantry couldn't advance. We stayed there two days and two nights, 130 men with only 16 Lewis guns...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Major Jay Gatsby. For Valor Extraordinary.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I'm sure that's not necessary...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Oh but it is though...! You see, I thought you ought to know something about my life. I... I don't want you to think I'm just some... some nobody. You see, old sport, I'm going to make a very big request of you today.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: A big request?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Yes. Yes... Miss Baker will explain everything when you take her to tea this afternoon.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Jordan...? What's she got to do with it?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Oh, I assure you it's nothing underhand. Miss Baker's an honest sportswoman; she'd never do anything that wasn't alright...

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Pull over!!! Pull over to the curb!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: All right, old sport! Alright.

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Right you are... Know you next time, Mr. Gatsby. Excuse me!

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: One of your old Oxford pals?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Well... actually, I was able to do the Commissioner a favor once; he sends a Christmas card every year.  I imagine he'll be at lunch too...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: By the time we reached the bridge I was impossibly confused...

Speaker: wolfsheim
Dialogue: Ah my boy...!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Meyer, Meyer...

Speaker: wolfsheim
Dialogue: You smell so good.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Mr. Carraway; my friend, Mr. Wolfsheim.

Speaker: wolfsheim
Dialogue: A wonderful pleasure, Mr. Carraway. I know all about you.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: wold
Dialogue: Of course! Mr. Gatsby is always talking about you.

Speaker: wolfsheim
Dialogue: Come, join us for a little lunch...

Speaker: wolfsheim
Dialogue: Tell Walter Chase; "he shuts his mouth or he doesn't get a penny..."

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: We'll talk about that later...

Speaker: head waiter
Dialogue: Highballs, Mr. Gatsby?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Yes, highballs it is.  You take good care of my friend here!

Speaker: commissioner
Dialogue: Hey Jay...! You're under arrest!!!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: You be careful now. You're turning into a real Jazz-Hound Commissioner.  See, that's the Commissioner back there.

Speaker: senator gulick
Dialogue: Of course! I'll put a bet on for you Jay!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Shall we order?  They decorate it with truffle slices and fine herbs. Very artistic.

Speaker: wolfsheim
Dialogue: So... How is the bond business Mr. Carraway?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: It's fine, thank you.

Speaker: wolfsheim
Dialogue: I understand you're looking for a BUSINESS GONNEGTION--

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: No, no. This isn't the man. This is the friend I told you about.

Speaker: wolfsheim
Dialogue: Oh! Beg your pardon, I had a wrong man.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Now, if you'll excuse me. I have to make THAT call.  Meyer, do you mind?

Speaker: wolfsheim
Dialogue: Gatsby! What a gentleman! From one of the finest families in the Midwest... Sadly all dead now. Let me tell you, when I made the pleasure of Mr. Gatsby's acquaintance just after the war, I knew I had discovered a man of fine breeding. A war hero! Such... medals. And, an Oggsford man. Oggsford College in England. You know Oggsford?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I've heard of it...

Speaker: wolfsheim
Dialogue: Then you would know that a man like that can be trusted. With a friend, with someone like you, he would never so much as look at your wife...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I'm not... married.

Speaker: wolfsheim
Dialogue: But you work on Wall Street, right?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Yes...

Speaker: wolfsheim
Dialogue: Looking at my tiepin?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Gentlemen. Everything alright...?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Oh, yes... We were just talking about other people's wives...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Other people's wives? Ah... I see.

Speaker: wolfsheim
Dialogue: Well, my work here is done. I'll leave you gentlemen to talk about your sports and your women...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: You'll have to excuse him... In his old age, he's prone to "digress..." He's a regular around here; a real denizen of Broadway...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Who is he anyhow?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Meyer? He's a gambler.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: An actor?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Meyer? No. He's the man who fixed the 1919 World Series.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Fixed it?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Fixed it.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: How did he manage that?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: He just... saw the opportunity, I suppose. He's a very smart man.  Now, old sport, about Miss Baker, and that request we spoke of...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Hey Nick! Nick! Where've you been!? Daisy's furious you haven't called up.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: This is Mr. Gatsby, Mr. Buchanan.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I'm so very, very... delighted to make your acquaintance.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I wouldn't have expected to find you in this temple of virtue.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I'm having lunch with Mr. Gats--

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I'm looking for Ms. Baker. Yes. The famous sporting star. The golfer... There... I've spotted her.

Speaker: maitre'd
Dialogue: Will the gentleman be joining?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: One moment please--

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Please, Nick, sit down. This is a polite restaurant.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: It's all very strange. He picks me up in his fancy yellow car... And he's going on and on and on about his life and the war and rubies and Oxford and... What is--

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: If you'll just have a seat--

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: What is this big request!?

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Nick--! He just wants you to invite Daisy to tea.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Tea?  Daisy...? And Gatsby...?

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Well... I don't know quite where to start. You see... I met Gatsby, five years ago, in Louisville...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: So what happened?

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Well, I don't know...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Tell them Daisy's changed her mind!

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Daisy! Please, everyone's waiting!

Speaker: young daisy
Dialogue: Give them back!!

Speaker: daisy's mother
Dialogue: What on earth is going on in here!?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Leave me alone!

Speaker: daisy's mother
Dialogue: Jordan, run the bath! Now!

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: After the honeymoon, I saw them in Santa Barbara. It was touching, actually...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: It's a strange coincidence, isn't it? Gatsby's house being just across the bay...

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: It's no coincidence. He bought that house to be near her, he threw all those parties hoping she'd wander in one night. He constantly asked about Daisy... I was the first one who knew her.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: All that for a girl he hasn't seen in five years...? And now he just wants me to have her for tea...?  The modesty of it.

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Kind of takes your breath away, doesn't it?

Speaker: taxi driver
Dialogue: Evening sweethearts! Where to?

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Long Island, please.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: And you think I should? I mean, does Daisy want to see Gatsby?

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: She's absolutely not to know. You are just supposed to invite her over so he can "happen to drop by."

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Your place looks like the World's Fair... or Coney Island!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Ah, does it? I've... I've just been glancing into some rooms... Let's go to Coney Island, old sport, we can take my car--

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: It's too late tonight.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Or we can take a plunge in the swimming pool? I haven't made use of it all summer...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I must go to bed...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Oh, that's alright. I don't want to put you to any trouble...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: What day would suit you?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: What day would suit you...? I don't want to put you to any trouble...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Day after tomorrow alright?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Day after tomorrow? Well, I'd... I'd want to get the grass cut.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Not really.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: If you'll pardon my... You see, I carry on a little business on the side - a sort of sideline - you understand what I'm saying right? You're selling bonds, aren't you, old sport?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Trying to.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Well, this might interest you... It happens to be a rather confidential sort of thing... But you might pick up a nice bit of money.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I've got my hands full.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: You wouldn't have to do any business with Wolfsheim. I assure you.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: No, no, no... Its a favor Jay. Just a favor.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: A favor?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Ah, right, right... Goodnight.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Goodnight.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: One of the papers said they thought the rain would stop about four. I think it was the Journal...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: The grass looks fine.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Grass?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Have you got everything you need?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Perhaps more flowers?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I think they did a fine job, don't you?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Beautiful.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: You think it's too much?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I think it's what you want.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I think so too... She'll be impressed, won't she old sport?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I am.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I can't wait all day. I'm leaving!

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Don't be silly. It's just two minutes to four...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Nobody's coming to tea. It's too late!

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: It's her.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Is this absolutely where you live, my dearest one?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: That's the secret of Carraway Castle.  Tell your chauffeur to go far away.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Come back in an hour, Ferdie!  His name is Ferdie.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: He is in love with me...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: That's funny.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: What's funny?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: One moment...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: I'm certainly glad to see you again.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I'm... certainly glad to see you as well.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: We've met before...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: It's an old... clock.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Lovely though. A lovely... clock.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Five years next November.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Tea?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Thank you old sport.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Darling thank you.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I just need to... pop into town.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Town...?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: The village; I'll be right back.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I've got to speak to you...!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Oh, God! This is a mistake, a terrible, terrible mistake...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: You're just embarrassed, that's all... Daisy's embarrassed too.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: She's embarrassed?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Just as much as you are.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Don't talk so loud!

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: You're acting like a little boy! You're rude. Daisy's in there all alone and...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Its... stopped raining.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Yes, it has...  Hasn't it?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Look. Its my house. Just there across the bay...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I know. I have the same view from my place.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Where's your place?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Nick, I want you and Daisy both to see my house. I'd like to show her around.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Are you sure you want me to come?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Absolutely, old sport. Absolutely.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I had the gates brought in from a castle in Normandy.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Oh, Jay...!? Its so grand!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Do you like it?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: I love it...! But how do you live here all alone?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I don't. I keep it always full of interesting, celebrated people...

Speaker: dausy
Dialogue: Come on you two! I want the royal tour!

Speaker: gatbsy
Dialogue: You must understand, I like all things that are modern.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: If you press this button here, the oranges shoot through here, are crushed there... The juice of 200 oranges extracted in one hour...!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Its a remarkable little camera-- latest design.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: You do know, I'm a champion golfer, don't you? Here, I'll show you how its done.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: She looks like she could be on the cover of Vogue, don't you think...?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Oh...! Its beautiful.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Its a custom Wurlitzer.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Can anyone play it?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Klipspringer can.  Someone wake Ewing!

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Music! And we can dance all night!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Ewing's a symphonic genius, he can play anything...!

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Then I demand a Charleston!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: She makes it look so splendid, don't you think old sport?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I've got a man in England who buys me clothes...!

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: I've never seen anything like it!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: He sends over a selection at the beginning of each season...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Jay!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: These are silk! Linen! Indian flannel! Egyptian cotton!

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: No, Jay... you'll ruin them!  Nicky! He's a madman!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: It's just... It makes me sad, because...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: ...because...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: It's just... Because I've never seen such beautiful shirts before.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: If it wasn't for the mist we could see the green light...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: What green light?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: The one that burns all night at the end of your dock.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Who's this? Your father?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: No, no.. That's Mr. Dan Cody, old sport... He's dead now. He used to be my best friend years ago.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: You never told me you had a pompadour... or a yacht.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I want to show you something... Look, here's a lot of clippings, about you.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: You saved my letters...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: This was my first photo of you.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Excuse me.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: I wish I had done everything on earth with you. All my life.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: It will be...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: You see doctor... Gatsby's real name was... James Gatz.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: He rowed out and rescued the vessel, and its captain, alcoholic millionaire Dan Cody...

Speaker: cody
Dialogue: Whadzamatta...?

Speaker: young gatsby
Dialogue: Sir! The shoal here's real bad, this wind could drag you onto it...

Speaker: cody
Dialogue: Whaderathinkyerdoin..., old sport?

Speaker: young gatsby
Dialogue: Gatsby. Jay Gatsby. A pleasure to meet you, sir. Gatsby. Jay Gatsby. Gatsby. Jay Gatsby.

Speaker: young gatsby
Dialogue: She looks well, doesn't she...!? Old sport.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: We've got a great band here. Have a look around... Excuse me...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: A lot of these newly rich people are just filthy bootleggers.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Not Gatsby. He's a businessman.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Hah! A businessman...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: He owned a lot of drug stores.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: May I introduce Senator Gulick? This is Mr. Carraway and Mrs. Buchanan...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Delighted...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: And Mr. Buchanan...  The polo player.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Oh no. Not me.

Speaker: senator gulick
Dialogue: Always a pleasure to meet a Buchanan.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'd rather not be the polo player.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Oh Tom... You should be proud of your achievements.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: May I show you around?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Absolutely!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: We don't go around very much. I don't think I recognize a single person...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Perhaps you know that lady there?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Its Marlene Moon... I adore her pictures...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'd really rather not be the polo player...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: These things excite me so...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I believe we've met somewhere before, Mr. Buchanan. About a month ago.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: That's right... And you were with Nick here. At the barbershop...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: That's right. See... I know your wife.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Is that so?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: herzog
Dialogue: Mr. Gatsby sir. Mr. Slagle is here...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Not now.

Speaker: trimalchio
Dialogue: And now...! Dice, Brass Knuckles and Guitars, with: The Foxtrot!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Mr. Buchanan, would you mind, terribly?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Of course not; I think I can keep myself amused.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: In case you need to take down any addresses...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Is all this made entirely from your own imagination?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: No... You see you were there all along, in every idea, in every decision... Of course, if anything is not to your liking, we can change it...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: It's perfect. From your perfect, irresistible imagination...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I wonder where the devil he met Daisy...?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Have you seen my wife...?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Ah... no... Not for awhile.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: That's funny. The Senator said he saw her down here.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: I... I wish we could just run away.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Run away? Darling, no. Daisy, that... that wouldn't be... respectable.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You live near here Nick...?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Just next door.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: That so...?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: We're going to live here, in this house, together. You and me... Daisy... It's time for you to tell Tom.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What a circus... Well, if you see her, I'll be looking for her. You tell her.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Remember how much fun we used to have? Why can't we just have fun like that again?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: What about?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: About things... About the future...  The future of the Colored Empires.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Well, its Tom. He's wandering around the party looking for you.

Speaker: herzog
Dialogue: Sir; it's Mr. Slagle; he's quite... emotional.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Excuse me. Nick, would you mind?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: But Gatsby was unable to return.

Speaker: wolfsheim
Dialogue: When these hot headed types appear, I rely on you... But you were not available.. A scene was made... What's going on with you Jay?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Where were you?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: With Nicky. Mr. Gatsby was showing us the grounds.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Well, he certainly must have strained himself to get that menagerie together...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Well there you are...! Daisy just left... But she asked me to tell you. She had a wonderful time...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: She didn't like it.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Of course she did.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: No, she didn't like it. She did not have a good time. I feel so far away from her now. It's hard to make her understand.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: You mean about the party?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: The party!? I couldn't care less about the parties! You see...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: What...?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Yes. Then we can go back to Louisville, to her parents' house - her parents are lovely people old sport - we'll be married there... You see, Daisy and I are going to and start over, just as if it were five years ago.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I wouldn't ask too much of her...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Ask too much?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I beg your pardon old sport. Its just.. Its so sad because its so hard to make her understand, and--

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Jay... You can't repeat the past.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Can't repeat the past?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Why of course you can. Of course you can. You'll see. I am going to fix things just the way there were before. Everything's been so... so confused since then...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: If I could just get back to the start... If I could just get back to the start I could find it again.

Speaker: daisy mom
Dialogue: Daisy, don't scamper.  There's so many dashing young officers here, and from such illustrious family's...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I knew that, that when I kissed this girl, I would... be forever wed to her...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: So I stopped. And I waited... I waited...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: And then I just let myself go.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I knew it was a great mistake for a man like me to fall in love. A great mistake. I'm only 32... I might still be a great man if I could only forget that I once lost Daisy. But my life, old sport, my life has got to be like this...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: I don't want to go home.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Then don't.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Yes... Daisy and I are very much in love.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Daisy comes over sometimes in the afternoons and I wanted some people who wouldn't gossip... until we decided what we're going to do... You see these two towns are pretty close together. And it gets in the papers... You understand?  They're some people Wolfsheim wanted to do something for.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Daisy needs you. I... We need you. Will you come old sport?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You know, I read somewhere that the sun's getting hotter every year...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I'm right across from you.  Right there.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: So you are.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Every night I can see that light at the end of your dock, blinking.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What light?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: You see, Mr. Buchanan, I wanted to be close-- Daisy and I--

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: It's so hot...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Town!? Women... They get these notions...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Daisy...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: You look so cool. You always look so cool, like the advertisement of the man... in Times Square...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Let's go to town! I'm perfectly willing...! That's a marvelous idea! Henri! Have the car brought around immediately!

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Just like that? Can't anyone at least have a cigarette?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: We've smoked all through lunch.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Oh, let's have fun. It's too hot to fuss.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: It was your great idea Daisy. Why don't we!? We'll all go to town!

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: I've changed my mind...  You brute.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You've got me all excited, and now you don't want to go? We'll get a great big room at the Plaza, a cold bucket of ice, and some whiskey... It will be fun.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Fine. Have it your own way, Tom... Come on, Jordan.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Will you join us, Mr. Gatsby?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Mr. Gatsby! Would you be good enough to take my coup? And I'll drive everyone else in your circus wagon.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I don't think there's much gas, old sport.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Isn't that right, Mr. Gatsby?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: You take Nick and Jordan, Tom!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You think I'm pretty dumb, don't you? But I have a-- an almost second sight, sometimes, that tells me what to do. And I've made a small investigation of this fellow.

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: And you found he was an Oxford man?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Oxford, New Mexico! He wears a pink suit for Christ's sake!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Wilson! Wilson! What are you waiting for!? Let's have some gas...  Do I have to do it myself?

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: I'm sick. I'm all run down. I need money bad... My wife and I want to go West.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Your wife does...?

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: I just got wised-up to something funny the last two days. She's goin' whether she wants to or not.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What do I owe you!?

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Dollar twenty.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You can have the car! I'll send it around tomorrow!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: That's enough...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Open another window.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: There aren't any more.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Then telephone for an axe...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Forget about the heat. You make it worse by crabbing about it.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Why not let her alone, old sport?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: That's a great expression of yours, isn't it?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: What is?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: 'Old sport'. Where'd you pick it up?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Now see here, Tom; if you're going to make personal remarks I won't stay here one minute.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Mr. Gatsby, I understand you're an Oxford man.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: No, not exactly.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Oh yes, I understand you went to Oxford.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Yes - I went there.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Sure; the man in the pink suit went to Oxford!

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Tom...!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I told you I went there.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I heard you, but I'd like to know when.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: You'd like to know when....? It was in nineteen-nineteen, I only stayed five months. That's why I can't exactly call myself an Oxford man.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: I'll make you a drink Tom, then you won't seem so stupid to yourself...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Wait a minute, I want to ask Mr. Gatsby one more question.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Go on. Please Mr. Buchanan, go on.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What kind of a row are you trying to cause in my house anyhow?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: He isn't causing a row; you're causing a row. Please have a little self-control!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Self-control! I suppose the latest thing is to sit back and let Mr. Nobody from Nowhere make love to your wife? Well, if that's the idea you can count me out... See, nowadays people begin by sneering at family life and family institutions and next you know they'll throw everything overboard and we'll have intermarriage between black and white!

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: We're all white here, Tom.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Your wife doesn't love you. She's never loved you. She loves me!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You must be crazy.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: No, old sport. See, she never loved you... She only married you because I was poor and she was tired of waiting. It was a terrible, terrible mistake, but in her heart she never loved anyone but me!

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: We should go...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Daisy and I have nothing to hide...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Jay let's go, please...!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Sit down Daisy!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Yes, Daisy, please sit down.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What's been going on? I want to hear all about it.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I just told you what's been going on; its been going on for five years...!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You've been seeing him for five years?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Not seeing. No, we couldn't; but both of us loved each other all that time, old sport, and you didn't know. I used to laugh sometimes, to think that you didn't know...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Oh - that's all; you're crazy! I can't speak about what happened five years ago, because I didn't know Daisy then - but I'll be damned if I see how you got within a mile of her unless you brought the groceries to the back door. But all the rest of that's a god-damned lie. Daisy loved me when she married me and she loves me now.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: She does, though... And what's more, I love Daisy too. Once in a while I go off on a spree, but I always come back, and in my heart I love her all the time...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: You're revolting...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: That's all over now. Just tell him the truth, that you never loved him; and all this... all this pain will be wiped out forever.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Why, how could I love him, possibly?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: You never loved him.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: I never loved him.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: That's right...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Not at Kapiolani?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Not that day I carried you down from the Punch Bowl to keep your shoes dry...? Daisy? Never?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Please don't.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Daisy...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: There, Jay.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: You loved me too?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Even that's a lie. She didn't know you were alive. There are things between Daisy and me that you'll never know, things that neither of us can ever forget.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I want to speak to Daisy alone. She's all excited now...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Even alone I can't say I never loved Tom. It wouldn't be true.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Of course it wouldn't.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: As if it mattered to you.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Of course it matters. I'm going to take better care of you from now on.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: You're not taking care of her any more! Daisy's leaving you.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Nonsense.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: I am, though.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: She's not leaving me; and certainly not for a common swindler!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: What about it, old sport?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Don't call me `old sport!' This drug store business is just small change compared to the bonds stunt you and Wolfsheim have got going on now.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Well your friend Walter Chase isn't too proud to come in on it.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I've been giving that some thought. How does a reputable banker like Walter Chase find himself up to his eyeballs in debt to a little kike like Wolfsheim?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: It's called `greed,' old sport.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: That's right; you've got half of Wall Street out there swilling your free booze at that fun park every weekend...  I'm surprised he hasn't tried to drag you in...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: He's got nothing to do with--

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: With your little racket...  Daisy... Can't you see who this guy is? With his house and his parties and his fancy clothes; he's just a front for Wolfsheim, a gangster, to get his claws into respectable folk like Walter...!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: The only respectable thing about you, old sport, is your money, that's it, and now I've just as much as you; so that means we're equal!!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Oh no, no, we're different; I am,

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: SHUT UP! SHUT UP! SHUTTT UP!!!!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: That's right Mr. Gatsby, show us those fine Oxford manners...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: My sincerest apologies. I... I seem to have lost my temper.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Daisy darling... None of this has any consequence. Don't listen to him Daisy.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Please Tom; I can't stand this anymore!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You two start on home...  In Mr. Gatsby's car.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Daisy...!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Want any of this? Jordan? Nick? Nick?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Want any?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: No... I just remembered - today's my birthday. I'm thirty.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Happy birthday...

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: God knows everything you've been doing!

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: He's here...

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: Stop, Tom, please, stop!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Wreck...! Good. Wilson will have a little business at last... Let's take a look..

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Must we?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Just a look.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: O, my Ga-od! O, my Ga-od!

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: Sir. Sir, I'm gonna have to ask you to step away--

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Get off me...!  I'm fine. I'm fine.

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: You knew her?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: No... Not really...

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: Well then I have to ask you to step back.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What happened...?

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: She ran out `inna road. Son-of-a- bitch didn't even stopus car.

Speaker: well-dressed man
Dialogue: I saw it! It was a yellow car; big yellow car.

Speaker: michaelis
Dialogue: Yeah, a big yellow duezy; custom job.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: You don't have to tell me what kind of car it was! I know what kind of car it was!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Pull yourself together...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Listen, I just got here from New York. I was bringing you the coup. That yellow car wasn't mine, do you hear? I haven't seen it all afternoon.

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: What color's your car?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Blue, a coup; we've come straight from New York.

Speaker: michaelis
Dialogue: Yeah, they just stopped...

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: Alright... Blue.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Who owns the yella' car...?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Fella named Gatsby; he's a crook, George. Gives those parties the papers are always talking about...

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Maybe he was the one foolin' with Myrtle; maybe that's why he killed her...?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Yeah. Maybe. Guy like that, who knows...

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Oh, Ga-od! Oh, my Ga-od!

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Gatsby. Something outta be done about a fella like that. He'll pay... Oh, he'll pay...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: The goddamn coward didn't even stop his car...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'll telephone for a taxi, Nick. Come in and have some supper while you wait...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: No thanks. I'll wait outside.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What is the matter with you?

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: Won't you come in, Nick?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: No... thanks.

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: It's only half past nine...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: No. I think I've had enough... Of everyone.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Hello old sport...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: What are you doing!?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Just sitting here...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Yes, I can see that.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Did you see any trouble out on the road?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Trouble!? That woman you ran down is dead Jay!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I thought so... I told Daisy I THOUGHTS SO--

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Daisy? Do you hear yourself--

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Its better that the shock should come all at once--

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: What's wrong with you!? How could you!?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Please... Keep your voice down, old sport.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Tom was right! You're nothing but a goddamn coward!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Keep your voice down... There. Was. No. Point. In. Stopping.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: NO POINT!?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: It, it killed her instantly. I--

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Yes, I was there. I saw! It ripped her open!

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I understand-- It was... my fault. This woman just rushed out, as if she wanted to speak to us... It all happened so quickly. She-- I... tried-- to turn the wheel.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: She?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: You see, after we left New York, she was very nervous. She thought driving would steady her. But this woman, she just rushed out at us.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Jay-- You shouldn't be here. You should get out of here.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: No. No. No. I'm going to wait. I'll wait all night if necessary. You see, Daisy's locked herself in her room, and she's going to turn her light off and on again if he tries to bother her about that unpleasantness this afternoon. If he tries ANY brutality whatsoever--

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Tom won't touch her. He's not even thinking about her...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Oh, I don't trust him, old sport. I don't trust him.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Alright. Alright... You wait here. I'll see if there's any commotion.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Would you do that for me? Thank you. Thank you, old sport.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Its going to be all right...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Jay? Everything alright...?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Oh, hello, old sport. Yes, yes, everything's just fine... About four o'clock she came to the window; she stood there... Then, well, she turned out the light... So...  Give me a hand will you old sport?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Jay... You oughtta go away.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Go away? I can't leave now. Not tonight.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Do you understand that a woman has been killed--?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Daisy's going to call in the morning. Then we'll make plans, to go away together.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: But Jay she--

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: She just needs time to think...  She'll call. In the morning. She just needs time to think.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: JAY--

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: She just needs to think. She's going to call in the morning.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: You know, I thought for awhile I had a lot of things... But the truth is... I'm empty.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: ...I can't describe to you how surprised I was to find out that I loved her, old sport. And that she loved me too.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I never realized just how extraordinary a nice girl could be.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I thought out my life with Daisy in it, trying to figure out how we could marry and struggle along on so many dollars a month...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: What was in the letter?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: The truth, the reason why after the war, I hadn't been able to return--

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: God sees everything.

Speaker: herzog
Dialogue: Mr. Gatsby sir, excuse me, Chicago calling sir.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Now now. Keep it open. For a personal call...

Speaker: herzog
Dialogue: A personal call? Of course.

Speaker: gardener
Dialogue: I'm going to drain the pool today, Mr. Gatsby.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Not today. It's so beautiful.  You know, old sport, I've never used that pool all summer?

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Jay, I've got to go. I have to work.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: I understand... Well, I'll walk you out.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I'll call you up.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Do, old sport, please do.  I suppose Daisy'll call too.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: I suppose so... Well... Goodbye.

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Daisy...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Daddy's taking care of his two favorite girls...

Speaker: pammy
Dialogue: But where are we going?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Just for a little trip. Just you, me, and daddy...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: We should go.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: Buchanan residence.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: May I speak to Mrs. Buchanan? It's Mr. Carraway, her cousin...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Well, when you see her, will you tell her, the funeral's tomorrow?

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: I'm sorry, but... They have gone away.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Please, I know she would want to be there. If you could just get a message to her--

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: GET OUT! ALL OF YOU OUT! GET OUT...!!!

Speaker: jordan
Dialogue: He threw all those parties hoping she would wander in one night...

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Its like an amusement park...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: But how do you live her all alone?

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: She makes it look so splendid, don't you think, old sport?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Music! And then we can dance all night...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: Will you come old sport? We... need you.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: I wish it could always be like this...

Speaker: gatsby
Dialogue: It will be...

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Its perfect... From your perfect, irresistible imagination.
